title: Will the Trans-Pacific Partnership be ratified by Congress before 20 January 2017?
preds: This is a no-brainer I couldn't resist. I only wish I had seen the question sooner.
No. Pretty easy, given that we're 5 days away.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
If the Republicans did not confirm Obama's Supreme Court nomination, then of course nothing else will be done in his presidency. He has literally been reduced to a lame duck president.

Trump has already said that TPP will not be approved since the consequences will be harmful for US workers and their economy. Trump advocates for increasinf tariffs and therefore this partnerships is unlikely to be approved
There is no indication from the legislative agenda that this will be done. Neither Democrats nor Republicans have anything to gain.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

I am just a simple algorithm. On each question, Iook at those players whom I follow, and copy the forecast of one of the several who have made the most recent forecasts. I only use my own judgment when deciding which one to follow if several have made recent forecasts.
With the new congress sitting, there it is highly unlikely that the TPP will be passed in the next 15 days.

Congress will do nothing before inauguration....

With the election of DJT, and the date it is nearly impossible that the TPP will be ratified.
With war of words between Trump and China it is unlikely to see any ratification of this partnership.
Due to statements Donald Trump has put forth during his campaign it is unlikely that Congress would ratify in advance of Donald taking office

Almost unlikely. Trump has indicated his opposition, and Congress is extremely unlikely to pass before he takes over
Election of Donald Trump and Republican Congress would make any push for the TPP too dangerous for any political entity to support.
This is not even a question  .

No support from Trump, incoming Congress, and insufficient support from existing Congress.

New administration has made it clear that no new regulations are to be signed before they have had time to review them.
I believe that the Republicans in Congress will take Trump at his word that he will back out of the deal and they will try to push it through before Obama leaves office.
There is no way Congress will put through a piece of legislation that is so contentious before the new administration begins.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
lame duck Obama wont even try to push it, in a quixotic stunt
Unlikely to be passed while Obama in office, Trumps clear objections to TPP likely mean it wont be passed, or at least delayed beyond Jan 2017.

This Nov. 23 NBC News article,  http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/trump-s-pledge-dump-tpp-just-first-step-anti-trade-n687191, notes that the death of the TPP may just the beginning of Trump's actions in the area of international trade. No forecast change to this question though.
there is no chance of this happening post election
Trump plans to scrap the TPP. So a ratification is most unlikely
I think Obama will push hard to get this done.  I also think Trump will ome in and modify, but not reverse, the TPP agreement.

There is almost no chance.  The agreement still needs approval of the EU, Germany are not considered to be very eager, it was blocked by an area of Belgium, and the incoming president said he wasnâ€™t a big fan (although this is worth very little).
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Republicans will drag their feet until the lame duck session is over, and the policy isn't a priority for trump.

Given the recent statements by both Mitch McConnell and Jeff Sessions (the party in power) on the slim prospects of the TPP in addition to the election of Trump (who ran on more economically protectionist sentiment) it seems unlikely that there is any political will or momentum for the TPP to have any chance of finding its way on a lame duck president's desk before January 20, 2017.

Because they are afraid that Trump won't let it go through, and too many of their donors will benefit from it

Trump is in office -- money is the only driving factor.

Not with the Republicans in control of both houses of the Congress and the Presidency (who ran against the Trade Deals). This  is DOA.

While i think it VERY LIKELY that the Trump Administration would kill any effort to pass this in a lame duck session I also think it very likely that the Lame Ducks will try to pass it if no other reason - to put Trump on record as opposing it.
Revised down from 15% on news that Congressional leadership has declared the deal dead. Will adjust revision later when I've had time to dive into it a little deeper.

Peru's Kuczynski suggests TPP should be re-negotiated by including China and Russia, while eliminating the US.  Looking for discussion at the upcoming APEC summit in Peru.  DTrump's collision with reality may be more difficult than TMay's was.

Why would the republicans change course now when their power grab is so near? They will not agree on this or any other major matter before Jan 20. They do not want Obama to score any more points. Mr Trump would like to show he's serious by renegotiating this deal or at least send it back for review. Still I leave a few procents chance: UK and Theresa May are looking to get a major new cooperation with China. If they close a deal within the next 2 months that makes the Republicans sweat, it might still be possible that they would agree to TPP. Also, any insights Mr Trump will get during the handover cooperation with Obama, might tilt the outcome. But I think it's unlikely for it to be ratified.
It dead for now , not going to happen unless organize labor gets a voice on the structure of the deal

Trump Win Is The Only Way To Stop TPP Catastrophe

Trump is going to rewrite this, Congress won't do anything beforehand.

the public globally is not in support
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

There is no political gain for the majority party to bring this to a vote... they will wait for the out come of the election: if POTUS is Republican, then they will vote to deny the TPP, if POTUS is Democrat, they will stall until mid-terms to get overwhelming majority to deny, if vetoed by PDem POTUS, they will over-rule the veto.  The only hope for TPP is Dem POTUS & Dem Congress!

A less politically charged environment and/or a diversion to more polarizing arguments to serve partisanship (e.g. Clinton indictment) has a small chance of creating a more rational environment to pass TPP on its merit.

For me, this is really a question about whether or not this will happen after the election. Right now, populism is on the rise and the Republicans aren't going to do anything drastic. The House Freedom Caucus will not be conciliatory to a Hillary Clinton win.

In order for the TPP to be passed, there must be a majority of Congressmen and Senators who either (a) have no ambitions to be reelected, (b) are elected in a safe district/state, or (c) are campaigning in a state where the TPP is more popular. The central assumption behind this is that the TPP is by and large unpopular, and thus does not help politicians in their campaign. Exceptions may hold for districts and states with large proportions of college-educated knowledge workers, such as California and New York City.

It's a big hot button issue, but it's only chance is if Obama gets it done before the next president.  Both candidates should support it but neither can so neither would fight if Obama pushed it.  However, it's probably not going to get enough traction.

Clinton wants very much for it to pass, but she doesn't want to have to support it, and have the left hate her for it.  So Obama and the corporate class, along with almost all Republicans, will ram it through.
Both parties have seen the voter aversion to opening US markets if it is likely to impact domestic employment.
There is little chance that any controversial legislation will be approved by 20 January 2017.
The Congress will not ratify anything  before 20 January 2017. The Congress will be plotting ways to defeat the president and how to address its own civil war.
HRC will win, and Congress will have ODD.

Both presidential candidates have indicated their resistance to the Trans-Pacific Partnership and can exercise their influence to prevent it passing. Furthermore, there are no external forces formidable enough to pressure the US into ratifying the treaty so it has almost no chance. What could happen, albeit after the deadline, is a renegotiation of the terms of the agreement and that agreement is agreed and ratified but that is likely to be beyond 2017.
Pressure to confirm Supreme Court Nominee will take all political capital before inauguration.
i think there's very little chance of this being ratified before next summer.
With the election over, Clinton will look to Obama to do it so she can maintain her "opposition."
Lame duck session of Congress and both candidates do not see it as advantageous for the country.
Too complex. Neither side has "ducks" in rows.  Unless the "lame" ducks decide, "what the hell?" and vote for TPP as they waddle out the door.
Paul  Ryan and Obama will push it

With the near failure of CETA between Canada and Europe, the tide is turning against trade deals with aspects of external legal-corporate settlement. TPP wanted too much, and didn't include all of the stakeholders in the negotiations.
Trade agreements require 2/3 of Senate for ratification, even with fast track approval, it is unlikely the Senate will vote in less than 90 days.

News out this morning suggests that if Hillary Clinton wins Obama is going to make a play for it in a lame duck session. However, the odds of that are still long, at best. At worst John Oliver steps in, and this is an overestimate.
With an election in a week, it is highly unlikely congress will be able to pass this
Trump does not support it. Clinton weakly supports it, but if elected, will be facing pushback from all directions.
They will get to this right after they ratify the Communist Manifesto.
Congress has no incentive to ratify TPP before the President takes office. Both parties will wait to assess the new administration's tone and await the installment of new Congressional leaders.
In the current political climate the TPP is dead on arrival for Congress.

A Vietnamese official says the country needs more time before it ratifies the Trans Pacific Partnership, dealing a blow to the trade deal, which includes the United States and Japan.
Vietnam needs more time before it ratifies the Trans Pacific Partnership, an official said Tuesday, dealing a blow to the trade deal that includes the United States and Japan.

Because i hear there is a greater than 50% probability that President Obama will pass the TPP in a lame Duck session of Congress while he still has enough votes to get it to pass before the next President will take the oath of Office so they can't be blamed for it's passage.
It is too vast and unpopular to pass in a lame duck session.

This will be another lame duck political two faced move.  Probably the Congressional vote will be Christmas Eve with the President signing on New Eve so that no one notices.  Both parties have candidates running against it.  Neither will be President before Jan 20 so they can avoid the word hypocrite.  Big money wants this and that is all we need to know.  It is much safer for the establishment to do this in a lame duck session than during a normal session.

So much division on this issue from both sides of the political spectrum. There are too many neo-populist and isolationist Republicans in congress, and there are too many Democrats fleeing the center.

The US has until early 2018 to ratify TPP, plenty of time to make changes and let the present toxic atmosphere of the election die down. This will almost certainly not even come up for a vote before the new administration takes office. Under a new administration the traditional republican support of trade may resurrect TPP.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Obama is committed to passing TPP and is going all out to do so supposedly, A vote in the 3-20th January window is likely therefore if Obama feels that he can win. The fast-track legislation, which was seen as a proxy vote on TPP, did pass but very narrowly. Given that the number of Democrats is likely to increase in Congress at the expense of Republicans who are more likely supporters of TPP, the mathematics will become worse not better. The anti-TPP mood in both parties is likely to further complicate matters.
Probably not.... however the political environment may be a little different after the election...
A trade agreement may eventually be done, but not for now and not with the name TPP>
Assuming that Hillary wins the election and Democrats take the Senate, she will probably not mind if Obama partners with the GOP to pass TPP.
HRC clearly against TPP passage in final debate.   Dems support for passage seems more unlikely now.
Obama can't get a Supreme Court nominee through, and Hillary Clinton's changed her position (though she will eventually sign a similar trade agreement.
I'm bullish on the TPP. I think there will be a big push before the transfer of power.

Hillary Clinton will almost certainly win the 2016 presidential election. But she won't be in office until 20 January 2017.  The "Lame Duck"
Congress will NOT pass a measure of such importance as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, especially if the Republicans lose the House in the 'down ticket' impacts of the presidential race.

I think Hilary has a 40% chance of winning. If she does she will push TPP through.
BUT it wouldn't get through by Jan.
Both leading presidential candidates are not yet supportive, but that can change.
Congress will be the next battle zone after the election. It's highly unlikely that TPP will get through that fast

There's no agreed final text as yet, there are greater time pressures on the lame-duck Congress (passing a Budget of some kind!), and the anti free trade members in the Senate are almost certainly large enough to sustain a filibuster.

I think it's higher than the current 1%. Supporters of the measure will likely push harder after the election results are in (so that it won't affect their election campaign) and it's unlikely that Donald or Hillary will ratify it so they must move quickly to get it done before the new president takes office.
It's too controversial as is. It is unlikely to be ratified until it's rewritten.
Too soon for Hillary to flip flop.  Too soon for Donald to do anything.
Despite heavy pushback from the Republican Base and Presidential Nominee Donald Trump, there is still a chance that many traditional conservatives would not oppose 'free trade agreements'.
Very difficult to pass the agreement in face of opposition by both candidates

I would go to ZERO but over the years Shumer and McConnell have repeatedly caved on promises, and this is the bell weather I watch to see if the Agenda in the lame duck session will be set by Congress or by Globalist.
If the Democratic party candidate wins, she will urge the halt to the ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership. This will give members of Congress and "out."
That would be awfully brazen of them.

As with other Obama legacy projects, the chance of the Republicans letting this happen is non-existent. Especially since both candidates now openly oppose the deal, the political atmosphere for the ratification does not exist.
It does not sound like it.
Lack of even uniform partisan support for the deal.  Congressional leadership has made it clear that they will not advance the TPP.  I see no upside for Congress, regardless of the next POTUS.

Congress understand that for the USA to prosper , the country cannot isolate itself from the rest of the world by protecting union jobs ,though I truly believe in the union. 
The union has to reinvent itself to suite the modern times. Fearful of union deserting the Democratic Party could put TPP in jeopardy.
Assuming Clinton is President and enough Republicans agree this trade agreement will help America.
Impossible to be done before the inauguration of the new US president.
Political environment is not suitable to pass a TPP this year

I have no idea why the good folks at Monkey Cage think this is a viable question -- McConnell clearly has ruled out bringing TPP up for a vote before the inauguration, and Schumer said he will not support it without something to address currency manipulation. I'm giving it 1% in case lightning strikes, but this is a VERY generous probability for lightning.

Trade deals in general and TPP in particular seem to have become popular scapegoats in this year in the US.  Along with Globalization they are blamed for cutting the wages of manufacturing worker. Although I read that more of the population in the US support free trade they are less keen than those who don't support free trade are against it. In these circumstances it sounds unlikely that Congress will risk trying to ratify it. The political costs are too high (voting for a deal that benefits big business) compared with the benefits (a claimed 1% increase in US GDP.

Treaties, as I recall, must be ratified by a two-thirds vote in the Senate.  It is likely that this settles the hash of the TPP until after the new Congress sits and after each party manages to find some adults who can settle things.   On the D side there are a fair number of these, although heir apparent Chuck Schumer is not among them.  Durbin could take the lead on this and get it done on that side, especially since at this point the Ds are much less fragmented, as long as they don’t need Bernie’s vote.

After the election the Republican leadership may not have to worry about reelection for a couple of years, but they will have to worry about retaining their positions within their parties.   I think there is sufficient opposition within congressional ranks on both sides to prevent the leadership from trying to pass it.  As much as I want it to pass,  I don't think it will.  This is just too hot of an issue.  Congressional leadership won't pass it because they want to retain their leadership positions in 2017.

In the United States, the Republican presidential aspirant Donald J. Trump has tapped into the rage of communities reeling from factory closings, denouncing trade with China and Mexico as a mortal threat to American prosperity. The Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton, has done an about-face, opposing an enormous free-trade deal spanning the Pacific that she supported while secretary of state.

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/29/business/economy/more-wealth-more-jobs-but-not-for-everyone-what-fuels-the-backlash-on-trade.html?emc=edit_ta_20160928&nlid=70183565&ref=cta&_r=0
For generations, libraries full of economics textbooks have rightly promised that global trade expands national wealth by lowering the price of goods, lifting wages and amplifying growth. The powers that emerged victorious from World War II championed globalization as the antidote to future conflicts. In Asia, Europe and North America, governments of every ideological persuasion have focused on trade as their guiding economic force.
In the boundless strangeness of the universe, a great many things are possible.  This is not one of them.

Because  in the FAQS  for this IFP it states and I have read that Majority Leader McConnell has vowed not to take up the bill in the Senate  until the end of the current  administration.  Assuming  control of the Senate  passes to Democrats  before the termination  date, no chance  based on the stated public positions of current  Democratic  incumbents  and any likely  elected  Senators  such as Tammy Duckworth  in Illinois.  
Given the current  hostility to existing  trade agreement  among many Republicans  and Democrats, I am forced to conclude  that like DAPA  the correct  forecast  is 0

It's pretty difficult to believe they're going to move on something this large/high profile that quickly considering Pres. candidates from both parties oppose it (esp. given McConnell is on record opposing a vote).
